</ref> the [[Five Precepts]] and the [[Noble Eightfold Path]] of [[Buddhism]] (''see'' [[Śīla]]); the ancient Egyptian code of [[Ma'at]]; the [[Ten Commandments]] of [[Judaism]] and [[Christianity]]; the [[Quran]] of Islam; Judaism's [[Noahide Law]]; and the [[yamas]] and [[niyama]] of the [[Hindu scriptures]].
−   −   −
== Human moral code according to the Monotheistic religions ==
  −
According to all monotheistic [[religions]] [[god]] is the only one that decided to [[human]] moral code of [[right]] or [[wrong]].
  −   −
All monotheistic [[religions]] agreed that the torah is [[god]] word given to the jews to make the humanity moral and good.
  −   −
[[Islam]] states that only the [[Torah]] was sent by the One true God.
  −   −
The [[Muslims]]' belief in the [[Torah]] is one of the fundamental tenets of [[Islam]].
  −   −
[[Christianity]] includes the five books of Moses (the Pentateuch) among their sacred texts in its [[Old Testament]].
  −   −
The [[Ten Commandments]] are a set of principles from the [[Torah]] relating to [[ethics]] and moral which play a fundamental role in the moral code of [[Judaism]] and most forms of [[Christianity]].
  −   −
== Morality vs Ethics ==
  −
[[Ethics]] and Morality both related to “right” and “wrong” conduct.
  −   −
Ethics are rules provided to an individual by an external source like the [[society]] or their profession.
  −   −
Morality are rules provided to an individual by Internal believe and according [[cultural]] norms like religions.
  −   −   −
== The Moral code in the individual decision making ==
  −
The morality purpose is to help the [[individual]] in making a right choose and do good and not bad.
  −   −
The [[individual]] human life involved making decisions.
  −
Some of them will right or wrong.
  −   −
[[Decision making]] can be regarded as the cognitive process resulting in the selection of a belief and/or a course of action among several alternative possibilities.
  −   −
Every decision making process produces a final choice.
